vectors.title: Preferred shapes
vectors.text:
Architecture patterns for AI
Preferred shapes
- **Edge scrubbers**: remove PII, enforce schemas, and reject unsafe inputs early. - **Retriever → Router → Model**: isolate each so you can upgrade independently. - **Policy layer**: a rules engine that can short-circuit a request before the model runs.

vectors.title: Observability defaults
vectors.text:
Architecture patterns for AI
Observability defaults
- Collect prompts and responses with hashed user identifiers. - Tag traces with model version, temperature, and data source. - Ship metrics to a privacy-aware backend (Plausible, OpenTelemetry collector).

vectors.title: Guiding principles
vectors.text:
AI Systems in Production
Guiding principles
- Treat models like dependencies: version, verify, and roll them back. - Separate **retrieval** from **reasoning** so you can swap LLM providers without touching business logic. - Instrument prompts like code: capture latency, token usage, and drift against golden test sets.

vectors.title: Hands-on
vectors.text:
AI Systems in Production
Hands-on
- Build a retrieval chain that caches embeddings locally for reproducibility. - Add lightweight red-teaming prompts to your CI so regressions are caught before deploy. - Use the Python cell below to experiment with token budgets and latency.

vectors.title: What to measure
vectors.text:
Evaluation you can automate
What to measure
- **Correctness**: reference answers or heuristics per intent. - **Safety**: jailbreak attempts, prompt injection, and PIIs leaking in outputs. - **Performance**: tail latency (p95/p99), cache hit ratio, and cost per request.

vectors.title: CI-friendly checks
vectors.text:
Evaluation you can automate
CI-friendly checks
- Small, curated datasets per use case. - Deterministic prompts with seeded randomness where possible. - Regression thresholds that stop a deploy when quality dips.

vectors.title: Big ideas to remember
vectors.text:
AI Summary and games
Big ideas to remember
AI is systems, not magic. A model is a component. The system is everything around it: data, interfaces, monitoring, fallbacks, and ownership. If the system is weak, a strong model just fails faster.

vectors.title: Common mistakes and myths
vectors.text:
AI Summary and games
Common mistakes and myths
Bigger models are not always better. Bigger can mean slower, more expensive, and harder to operate. Sometimes a smaller model with a better data path wins.

vectors.title: Mental models that actually help
vectors.text:
AI Summary and games
Mental models that actually help
If you are stuck, return to input, model, output. What inputs does the system really see. What does the model output. What happens next. Many failures are a mismatch between what the team thinks is happening and what is actually wired up.

vectors.title: What you will build
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
What you will build
- A repeatable threat model using the **CIA triad** tied to each OSI layer. - A control stack that stays traceable from intent through to enforcement. - A cryptography habit you can trust because it runs on the Web Crypto API, not ad-hoc code.

vectors.title: Controls by layer
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
Controls by layer
- **Business**: Define who is protected and why. Record the value-at-risk, sponsor, and acceptable downtime. - **Information (Data)**: Classify what flows across the OSI stack. Label PII, secrets, and operational telemetry separately. - **Application**: Enforce least privilege in code paths. Prefer signed tokens over shared secrets. Short TTLs, zero implicit

vectors.title: How to study
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
How to study
1. Skim the overview, then jump into the RSA lab to verify your cryptographic assumptions. 2. Use the CIA traceability list below as your checklist during architecture reviews. 3. Share your own playbooks by dropping new MDX lessons into .

vectors.title: CIA traceability checklist
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
CIA traceability checklist
- Confidentiality: classification present, key management defined, access logged and alerting active. - Integrity: signed artefacts, reproducible builds, change control with approvals. - Availability: capacity plan, DoS strategy, backup + restore tested with RTO/RPO targets.

vectors.title: Signals that matter
vectors.text:
Detection and response playbook
Signals that matter
- **Network (OSI 3-4)**: flow logs, TLS fingerprints, rate anomalies. - **Application (OSI 5-7)**: auth failures by IP, token reuse, impossible travel, schema misuse. - **Platform (OSI 1-2)**: CPU throttling, packet drops, kernel logs, node restarts.

vectors.title: Build the response muscle
vectors.text:
Detection and response playbook
Build the response muscle
1. Create a "golden path" request and response sample for each critical user journey. 2. Write one detection per journey that flags data exfil, tampering, or abuse. 3. Simulate failure: kill a service, expire a token early, or inject a fake credential leak.

vectors.title: Quick OSI-to-control map
vectors.text:
Detection and response playbook
Quick OSI-to-control map
- Physical/Data Link: link monitoring, port isolation, 802.1X. - Network: zero trust segmentation, egress allow-listing. - Transport: mTLS with rotated client certs, cipher suite policy. - Session/Presentation/Application: JWT expiry, content validation, WAF rules tuned to your domain vocabulary.

vectors.title: Why RSA here?
vectors.text:
RSA key generation lab
Why RSA here?
RSA still underpins S/MIME, VPNs, and legacy identity providers. When you control the key lifecycle you control the blast radius.

vectors.title: Generate a pair
vectors.text:
RSA key generation lab
Generate a pair
Pick your modulus length. 2048 is balanced for most web apps; 4096 is safer but slower on constrained devices.

vectors.title: Hardening tips
vectors.text:
RSA key generation lab
Hardening tips
- Store private keys in an HSM or KMS where possible; if local, encrypt at rest and rotate. - Use different key pairs for transport (RSA-OAEP) and signing (RSA-PSS or ECDSA). - Keep PEMs short-lived. Automate rotation via CI/CD, and prefer mTLS between services for machine identity.

vectors.title: Mathematical foundations of data systems
vectors.text:
Data Advanced
Mathematical foundations of data systems
Maths in data systems describes patterns, uncertainty, and change. Abstraction turns messy reality into numbers we can reason about. At small scale numbers feel friendly. At large scale tiny errors compound and variation matters more than single values.

vectors.title: Data models and abstraction at scale
vectors.text:
Data Advanced
Data models and abstraction at scale
Models are simplified representations of reality. They exist so teams can agree on how data fits together. Abstraction hides detail to make systems manageable. The risk is that hidden detail was needed for a decision you care about.

vectors.title: Advanced analytics and inference
vectors.text:
Data Advanced
Advanced analytics and inference
Inference is about drawing conclusions while admitting uncertainty. Correlation means two things move together; causation means one affects the other. Mistaking correlation for causation leads to confident but wrong decisions.

vectors.title: Data platforms and distributed systems
vectors.text:
Data Advanced
Data platforms and distributed systems
Data systems distribute to handle scale and resilience. Latency is the time it takes to respond. Consistency is how aligned copies of data are. Failures are normal in distributed systems, so we plan for them instead of hoping they do not happen.

vectors.title: Governance, regulation and accountability
vectors.text:
Data Advanced
Governance, regulation and accountability
Regulation exists to protect people and markets. Accountability means someone can explain what data is used, why, and with what safeguards. Auditability means we can trace who did what and when. These are not just legal boxes; they build trust with users and stakeholders.

vectors.title: Data as a strategic and economic asset
vectors.text:
Data Advanced
Data as a strategic and economic asset
Data creates value when it improves decisions, products, and relationships. Network effects appear when sharing makes each participant better off. Competitive advantage comes from combining quality data with disciplined execution, not from hoarding alone.

vectors.title: What data is and why it matters
vectors.text:
Data Foundations
What data is and why it matters
Data starts as recorded observations: numbers on a meter, text in a form, or pixels in a photo. When we add structure it becomes information that people can read. When we apply it to decisions it becomes knowledge. Data existed long before computers: bank ledgers, census books, medical charts. Modern systems are data driven because every click, sensor, and t

vectors.title: Data representation and formats
vectors.text:
Data Foundations
Data representation and formats
Computers store everything using bits (binary digits) because hardware can reliably tell two states apart. A byte is eight bits, which can represent 256 distinct values. Encoding maps symbols to numbers, while a file format adds structure on top. CSV is plain text with commas, JSON wraps name value pairs, XML uses nested tags, images store grids of pixels, a

vectors.title: Data quality and meaning
vectors.text:
Data Foundations
Data quality and meaning
Quality means data is accurate (close to the truth), complete (not missing key pieces), and timely (fresh enough to be useful). A sensor reading of 21°C is useless if the timestamp is missing. Noise is random variation that hides patterns, while signal is the meaningful part. Bias creeps in when some groups are missing or when measurements are skewed. Models

vectors.title: Data lifecycle and flow
vectors.text:
Data Foundations
Data lifecycle and flow
Data starts at collection, gets stored, processed, shared, and eventually archived or deleted. Each step has design choices: where to store, how to process, how to secure, and when to retire. Software architecture cares about where components sit. Cybersecurity cares about protection at each hop. AI pipelines care about how raw data becomes features.

vectors.title: Data roles and responsibilities
vectors.text:
Data Foundations
Data roles and responsibilities
Roles exist so someone is accountable for quality, access, and change. Data owners make decisions about purpose and access. Data stewards guard definitions, metadata, and policy. Data engineers build and maintain pipelines. Data analysts turn data into insights. Data consumers use the outputs responsibly. When roles blur, pipelines stall, privacy is ignored,

vectors.title: Foundations of data ethics and trust
vectors.text:
Data Foundations
Foundations of data ethics and trust
Ethics matters from the first data point. Consent means people know and agree to how their data is used. Privacy keeps personal details safe. Transparency builds trust because people can see what is collected and why. Misuse often starts with shortcuts: copying data to test faster or sharing beyond the agreed purpose. Trust erodes slowly and is hard to rebui

vectors.title: How data connects everything you learn next
vectors.text:
Data Foundations
How data connects everything you learn next
Data is the common thread across the other courses. AI models are only as good as the data they learn from. Cybersecurity controls protect data wherever it sits or moves. Software systems are structured flows of data shaped by design choices. Digital transformation is largely about improving how data is collected, shared, and trusted across journeys. Think o

vectors.title: Data architectures and pipelines
vectors.text:
Data Intermediate
Data architectures and pipelines
Data architecture is how data is organised, moved, and protected across systems. It sets the lanes so teams can build without tripping over each other. Pipelines exist because raw data is messy and scattered. They pull from sources, clean and combine, and land it where people and products can use it.

vectors.title: Data governance and stewardship
vectors.text:
Data Intermediate
Data governance and stewardship
Governance is agreeing how data is handled so people can work quickly without being reckless. Ownership is the person or team that decides purpose and access. Stewardship is the day to day care of definitions, quality, and metadata. Accountability means someone can explain how a change was made and why.

vectors.title: Interoperability and standards
vectors.text:
Data Intermediate
Interoperability and standards
Interoperability means systems understand each other. It is shared meaning, not just shared pipes. Standards help: common formats, schemas, and naming. A schema is the agreed structure and data types. When systems misalign, data lands in the wrong fields, numbers become strings, or meaning gets lost.

vectors.title: Data analysis and insight generation
vectors.text:
Data Intermediate
Data analysis and insight generation
Analysis is asking good questions of data and checking that the answers hold up. Descriptive thinking asks what happened. Diagnostic thinking asks why. Statistics exist to separate signal from noise: averages summarise, distributions show spread, trends show direction.

vectors.title: Risk, ethics and strategic value
vectors.text:
Data Intermediate
Risk, ethics and strategic value
Data risk is broader than security. Misuse, misinterpretation, and neglect can harm people and decisions. Ethics asks whether we should use data in a certain way, not just whether we can. Strategic value comes from using data to improve services, not just to collect more of it.

vectors.title: What you now understand about data
vectors.text:
Data Summary and games
What you now understand about data
You have moved from defining data to designing and governing it. Foundations gave you language and habits. Intermediate taught you to design systems and guardrails. Advanced pushed you to reason mathematically, architecturally, and strategically. The real shift is mindset: data work is judgement, context, and humility, not just numbers or tools.

Data fuels AI models and shapes their limits. Data failures lead to cybersecurity incidents and trust loss. Data design and contracts make software architecture coherent. Digital transformation only works when data is collected, shared, and trusted across journeys.

Why digitalisation matters
Digitalisation matters because expectations are higher, services are more complex, and regulation is tighter. In energy, the pressure is even greater: net zero targets, real time grid data, and consumer trust all depend on digital capability.

vectors.title: Risks, governance and people
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Foundations
Risks, governance and people
Digitalisation creates new risks: data quality problems, weak ownership, and security gaps. Governance makes those risks visible and managed. People still do the work, so roles and responsibility must be clear.

vectors.title: Data pipelines and flows
vectors.text:

Data pipelines and flows
A A sequenced flow that moves data from source to usable output. is only valuable when each step is owned and tested. Pipelines fail quietly when ownership is unclear or data quality is ignored.

vectors.title: APIs and system integration
vectors.text:

APIs and system integration
APIs are the contracts that keep systems aligned. A A call a system sends to another system when an event happens. supports real time updates without constant polling.

vectors.title: Data models and mapping
vectors.text:

Data models and mapping
A shared data model keeps systems aligned. The rules that translate fields from a source schema into a shared model. is where meaning is preserved or lost.

vectors.title: Operations, monitoring and observability
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Intermediate
Operations, monitoring and observability
Monitoring must cover both speed and safety. If you only watch speed, you miss quality. If you only watch quality, you miss delivery friction.

Big picture recap
Digitalisation matters because it changes how value is created and trusted, not just which tools are used. It joins policy, data, platforms, and people into one system that must work together.

vectors.title: Objectives
vectors.text:
Software Architecture for Operators
Objectives
- Tie every capability to a measurable outcome and a security intent. - Use the **C4 model** for clarity and align controls at each layer. - Keep non-functional requirements visible by default: latency, availability, privacy, and operability.

vectors.title: Artefacts you will produce

Artefacts you will produce
- **Capability map** that traces to epics and service ownership. - **Service contracts** that capture ingress, egress, and trust zones. - **Decision records (ADRs)** for trade-offs. Each ADR references threat models and runbooks.

vectors.title: What software architecture actually is
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
What software architecture actually is
Architecture is decision making under constraints. You are deciding what the system is allowed to do, what it must never do, and what it will trade to get there. The work is not drawing boxes. The work is picking the decisions that keep change affordable later.

vectors.title: What this optimises for
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
What this optimises for
- Shared understanding across a team - Cheaper change later through explicit decisions - Fewer surprises when systems grow or change hands

vectors.title: What this makes harder
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
What this makes harder
- You have to write decisions down and defend them - You might slow short term delivery to reduce long term risk

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain what decision is being made in an architecture discussion, not just the diagram - Explain the trade off being accepted and what constraint caused it - Explain why clear decisions reduce risk for security, data, and AI systems

vectors.title: Components, boundaries and interfaces
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
Components, boundaries and interfaces
Architecture starts to become real when you can name the parts and explain how they talk. A component is not just a folder. It is a unit of responsibility with a purpose and a shape that can be explained.

vectors.title: Layered architecture
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
Layered architecture
Layering is common because it controls dependency direction. It reduces blast radius by keeping low level details from leaking into core logic. It also improves auditability because you can reason about where checks and decisions happen.

vectors.title: Microservices vs monolith
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
Microservices vs monolith
This is not a morality contest. A monolith can be a good architecture if boundaries are clear and the deployment is reliable. Microservices can be a good architecture when independent scaling, team autonomy, or regulatory separation genuinely matter.

vectors.title: Centralised vs decentralised data
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
Centralised vs decentralised data
Centralised data can reduce duplication and make reporting easier. Decentralised data can reduce coupling and allow components to evolve independently. The decision is not abstract. It changes who owns quality, who approves schema changes, and how incidents are investigated.

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain why boundaries reduce change cost and security risk - Explain what breaks when interfaces are implicit or data ownership is unclear - Explain the trade off behind layering, microservices, and data ownership decisions

vectors.title: Thinking in systems, not code
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
Thinking in systems, not code
Most real failures are not inside one function. They happen in interactions: timeouts, retries, queue backlogs, and assumptions between services. A system can be correct in each part and still fail as a whole.

vectors.title: What this optimises for
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
What this optimises for
- Predictable behaviour under failure - Smaller incidents with clearer blast radius

vectors.title: What this makes harder
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
What this makes harder
- You must invest in guardrails, monitoring, and practice - Some optimisations are constrained by safety budgets

vectors.title: AI automation vs human oversight
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
AI automation vs human oversight
Automation can reduce workload and improve consistency. Oversight keeps accountability with people and catches failures before they scale. In real systems you usually want both: automation for low risk cases, and human review where the cost of a mistake is high.

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain how feedback loops create incidents without any single bug - Explain why retries and timeouts are architectural decisions - Explain why AI monitoring, versioning, and rollback are part of system design

vectors.title: Quality attributes and trade offs
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
Quality attributes and trade offs
Quality attributes are the "how" of a system, not the "what". The what is features. The how is performance, reliability, security, and everything that decides whether the system is usable and safe in real life.

vectors.title: What this optimises for
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
What this optimises for
- Decisions aligned to business and risk priorities - Clear justification for cost and complexity

vectors.title: What this makes harder
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
What this makes harder
- You have to say no to some goals and features - You must budget time for non feature work like testing and observability

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain what a design is optimising for and what it makes harder - Explain how the same decision affects security posture and data governance - Explain why operability and testability are part of professional accountability

vectors.title: Architecture as a professional discipline
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Foundations
Architecture as a professional discipline
Architecture is about trade offs. You are making choices under constraints and living with the consequences. The job is not to pick trendy patterns. The job is to make the system understandable, operable, and safe for its context.

vectors.title: Architecture styles in the real world
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Intermediate
Architecture styles in the real world
The big styles are patterns, not rules. A A single deployed system where most responsibilities live together. can be right for speed. A One deployable system with clear internal modules. gives structure without operational sprawl.

vectors.title: Integration and APIs
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Intermediate
Integration and APIs
Systems talk in two main ways. A A request where the caller waits for a response. feels simple but creates tight coupling. An A message sent without waiting for an immediate response. decouples systems but adds coordination work.

vectors.title: Quality attributes and trade offs
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Intermediate
Quality attributes and trade offs
Architects balance these qualities rather than chase perfection. A fast system that fails often is not success.

vectors.title: Data, state and consistency
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture Intermediate
Data, state and consistency
State hides everywhere. It lives in databases, caches, and message queues. How aligned different parts of the system are at the same time. comes in two main flavours. A style where parts may disagree for a short time, but they line up if we wait. is common in distributed systems.

vectors.title: Choosing boundaries
vectors.text:
Patterns and boundaries
Choosing boundaries
- Decompose by **business capability**, not by database table. - Protect **data ownership**: the service that owns data enforces rules; consumers read via contracts. - Prefer asynchronous integration for resilience; reserve sync calls for user journeys that need immediacy.

vectors.title: C4 sketch to start
vectors.text:
Patterns and boundaries
C4 sketch to start
1. Context: who uses the system and why? 2. Container: which deployable units exist and which trust zone are they in? 3. Component: how do modules expose capabilities and guardrails? 4. Code: link to docs and linters that enforce the rules.

vectors.title: Operability as design
vectors.text:
Runbooks and decision records
Operability as design
- Every service has a **runbook** with steady-state SLOs, alerts, and safe to retry guidance. - **ADRs** capture trade-offs and security posture. Link to threat models and test evidence. - **Golden paths**: templates for new services with logging, metrics, and trace exports enabled by default.

vectors.title: Sample ADR outline
vectors.text:
Runbooks and decision records
Sample ADR outline
- Context: what changed in the business layer? - Decision: what pattern or control did we select? - Consequences: which risks reduce, which move, which increase? - Verification: how do we know it works (tests, synthetic probes, chaos experiments)?

vectors.title: You made it to the end
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture: Summary and games
You made it to the end
You started with the basics of systems and roles. You moved through architecture styles and integration. You finished with domains, resilience, and evolution. That is real progress.

vectors.title: One page recap of the big ideas
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture: Summary and games
One page recap of the big ideas
Architecture stays healthy when boundaries are clear and decisions are visible.

vectors.title: Games and labs
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture: Summary and games
Games and labs
These short activities are here to keep your intuition sharp. Treat them like warm up drills before real work.

vectors.title: What next
vectors.text:
Software Development and Architecture: Summary and games
What next
If diagrams still feel fuzzy, revisit Foundations. If integration or data felt heavy, revisit Intermediate. If domains and distributed patterns need time, revisit Advanced and pick one topic to go deeper on.

vectors.title: Transformers and attention as information routing
vectors.text:
AI Notes, Advanced
Transformers and attention as information routing
Attention is weighted routing, not memory. The context window is a hard wall, not a soft suggestion.

vectors.title: Large language models as probabilistic systems
vectors.text:
AI Notes, Advanced
Large language models as probabilistic systems
LLMs optimise likelihood, not truth. Fluency is not reliability.

vectors.title: Retrieval, grounding, and embeddings
vectors.text:
AI Notes, Advanced
Retrieval, grounding, and embeddings
Grounding reduces hallucination; it does not erase it. Retrieval quality matters more than model size.

vectors.title: Agentic systems and tool use
vectors.text:
AI Notes, Advanced
Agentic systems and tool use
An agent is a loop: observe, plan, act, observe. Each loop compounds error.

vectors.title: Detection and operations at scale
vectors.text:
AI Notes, Advanced
Detection and operations at scale
Prevention fails. Detection and response decide whether failure becomes disaster.

vectors.title: Supply chain and systemic risk
vectors.text:
AI Notes, Advanced
Supply chain and systemic risk
Dependencies are attack paths. Trust is rarely isolated.

vectors.title: Governance, safety, and limits
vectors.text:
AI Notes, Advanced
Governance, safety, and limits
Governance is not paperwork. It is how we make decisions under uncertainty and accept residual risk honestly.

vectors.title: What AI is and why it matters now
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
What AI is and why it matters now
AI is a way of learning patterns from data so a system can make predictions, rank options, or automate decisions.

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain what a model is and why it exists in a system - Explain what breaks when training data and real inputs diverge - Explain the trade off between automation speed and human judgement

vectors.title: Data and representation
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
Data and representation
In AI, the word Data is recorded observations about the world. It is what the model learns from, not what we wish was true.

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain why representation choices change what a model can learn - Explain what breaks when labels, groups, or context are missing from data - Explain the trade off between simple features and richer embeddings

vectors.title: Supervised and unsupervised learning
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
Supervised and unsupervised learning
When we say a model learns, we mean it changes its internal settings so it can make better guesses. It is not learning like a person learns. It is closer to practice. You show examples, it adjusts, and it gets less wrong over time.

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain when supervised learning is appropriate and what it optimises for - Explain when unsupervised learning is useful and why evaluation is harder - Explain what breaks when people treat model outputs as understanding

vectors.title: Responsible AI basics and limitations
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
Responsible AI basics and limitations
AI systems can cause harm even when everybody is trying to do the right thing. The harm is not always dramatic. Sometimes it is quiet and personal. Someone is incorrectly flagged as suspicious. Someone does not get offered an opportunity. Someone is pushed into a bubble of content that makes them angrier and more certain.

vectors.title: What this optimises for
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
What this optimises for
- Automation speed and consistency for low risk tasks - Scaled assistance when humans have time and context

vectors.title: What this makes harder
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
What this makes harder
- Accountability if oversight is vague - Safe rollback when models drift or fail

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:
vectors.text:
AI Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain why models do not understand intent or truth and what breaks if you trust them blindly - Explain why evaluation and monitoring are continuous, not a one time step - Explain the trade off between AI automation and human oversight in high impact decisions

vectors.title: Prompts and patterns
vectors.text:
AI Intermediate
Prompts and patterns
Prompts are not magic, they are instructions. A The instruction or input you give a model to get a response. works best when it is clear about the task, the format, and the boundaries. A A higher level instruction that sets the role, rules, and tone for the model. should be stable and reviewed, not improvised in production.

vectors.title: Embeddings and vector search
vectors.text:
AI Intermediate
Embeddings and vector search
Embeddings turn text, images, or audio into numeric vectors. A A numeric representation that keeps some meaning so similar items are close together. lets me compare ideas by distance. A A specialised database for storing vectors and searching them by similarity. powers semantic search, recommendation, and clustering.

vectors.title: Retrieval with your own documents
vectors.text:
AI Intermediate
Retrieval with your own documents
Retrieval augmented generation, often called RAG, lets a model answer using your documents. It works by chunking documents, embedding the chunks, and retrieving the best matches for a query. The model then answers using the retrieved context.

vectors.title: Simple agents that use tools
vectors.text:
AI Intermediate
Simple agents that use tools
An A model that plans a sequence of steps and can call tools to reach a goal. is useful for multi step tasks, but it needs guardrails. A A request from the model to run a function or external action. should be limited, logged, and reviewed when risk is high.

vectors.title: Cryptography in practice
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Cryptography in practice
Crypto is only useful when it is applied correctly. Most organisations do not lose because the maths was broken. They lose because assumptions drift, keys leak, validation gets skipped, or somebody treats "encrypted" as a risk stamp that means "safe".

vectors.title: Secure architecture and zero trust thinking
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Secure architecture and zero trust thinking
Zero trust is simple: never assume the network is friendly, always verify access, limit blast radius. Design where no implicit trust is granted based on network location. Breaking systems into small zones with tight policy reduces how far an attacker can move. Defence in depth still matters: identity, network, application, and data controls should stack.

vectors.title: Detection, response and threat hunting
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Detection, response and threat hunting
Detection closes the gap between compromise and action. A Security information and event management (SIEM), a platform that collects and correlates security events feeds alerts to a security operations centre (SOC), a team that monitors and responds. Good detection reduces how long an attacker stays unnoticed. Response follows a loop: triage, contain, eradic

vectors.title: Governance, frameworks and your career
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Governance, frameworks and your career
This section is the glue. It is temporary tooling in a way, because your first versions will be imperfect. That is normal. The point is to build a loop that makes the next version better.

vectors.title: Security as an organisational capability
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Security as an organisational capability
Cyber is not only for the security team. Product decisions create attack surface. Procurement decisions create supply chain risk. HR decisions shape onboarding and offboarding. Finance decisions shape tooling and staffing. Operations decisions shape patch windows and incident response. In real organisations, the best security work looks like good coordinatio

vectors.title: Policies, standards, and reality
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Policies, standards, and reality
Policy, standard, procedure, and control are related but different.

vectors.title: Incident response and learning loops
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Incident response and learning loops
Incidents are noisy and emotional. Good teams make them boring on purpose.

vectors.title: Measuring security without lying to yourself
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Measuring security without lying to yourself
Most security metrics are activity that looks reassuring but does not reduce real risk because they measure activity, not risk reduction. Counting completed training, scanned hosts, or patched tickets tells you effort. It does not tell you outcome.

vectors.title: Ethics, trust, and long term resilience
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
Ethics, trust, and long term resilience
Security decisions affect people. Privacy is not a feature. It is a power question. Consent matters because users rarely have equal bargaining power. A short term win that surprises users can become a long term trust loss. Trust is slow to earn and fast to burn.

vectors.title: Foundations overview
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
Foundations overview
Cybersecurity is about reducing real harm. It protects people, not just computers. It protects money, time, safety, privacy, and trust. When it goes wrong, it often looks ordinary at first. A bank transfer goes to the wrong place. A delivery address changes. A clinic cannot open a record. A small mistake becomes a big mess.

vectors.title: Assets, threats, and risk
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
Assets, threats, and risk
An An asset is anything you care about enough to protect, like data, systems, people, time, and trust. It includes obvious things like customer records and laptops, but also things like staff time, reputation, and the ability to keep operating. If payroll fails on Friday, that is an availability problem. If a patient record is wrong, that is an integrity pro

vectors.title: Identity, access, and trust
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
Identity, access, and trust
Identity is now the security perimeter because work happens everywhere. Staff work from home. Phones are used for approvals. Vendors have access. Cloud services connect to other cloud services. The question is no longer only "is the network safe". The question is "who is this, and what should they be allowed to do".

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:

- Explain why representation and parsing mistakes create security risk - Explain what breaks when systems disagree on how bytes should be interpreted - Explain why integrity controls depend on correct data handling

vectors.title: Defence, detection, response
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
Defence, detection, response
Prevention alone fails. Not because people are lazy, but because systems are complex. Something will slip. A password will leak. A laptop will go missing. A supplier will get compromised. Defence needs layers, and it needs feedback.

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:

Cybersecurity Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain why trust boundaries exist and what breaks when networks are assumed safe - Explain how metadata can leak behaviour even when content is encrypted - Explain why monitoring often starts with patterns, not secrets

vectors.title: Confidentiality, integrity, availability and simple attacks
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
Confidentiality, integrity, availability and simple attacks
To keep this practical, we will use one simple frame: confidentiality, integrity, and availability, often shortened to CIA. Confidentiality means only the right people can see information. Integrity means changes are correct and visible. Availability means systems are there when needed. The purpose is not to memorise three words. The purpose is to ask better

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:

After this section you should be able to:
- Explain CIA as decision questions, not memorised words - Explain what breaks when identity is weak or integrity is not monitored - Explain why availability needs planning, not hope

vectors.title: Human factors and governance
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Foundations
Human factors and governance
Humans are not the weakest link. Humans are the system. Most insecure behaviour is a rational response to a bad setup. If it takes five minutes to do the safe thing, people will do the fast thing. If approvals block urgent work, people will route around them. If security tools produce noise, people will ignore them.

vectors.title: After this section you should be able to:

Cybersecurity Foundations
After this section you should be able to:
- Explain why humans are part of the system and what breaks when processes are unrealistic - Explain governance as ownership of trade offs, not documents - Explain why clear roles and rehearsed response reduce harm

vectors.title: Chapter 3 Advanced Building secure systems that survive real attackers
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Chapter 3 Advanced Building secure systems that survive real attackers
Chapter 1 gave us the foundations of data, harm, and basic security properties. Chapter 2 showed how trust breaks across networks and how encryption, identity, and integrity are stitched back together.

vectors.title: Threat modelling choosing what to defend and why
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Threat modelling choosing what to defend and why
In earlier chapters, we talked about harm and trust. Threat modelling is where we turn that into a repeatable method. It answers a simple question: what could go wrong in this system, how would it happen, and what would we do about it.

vectors.title: What threat modelling produces
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
What threat modelling produces
A good threat model produces four things: A clear system boundary A list of assets worth protecting A set of realistic attacker goals A set of controls mapped to specific failure modes

vectors.title: A minimal threat model structure you can reuse
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
A minimal threat model structure you can reuse
1 Describe the system in one paragraph 2 Identify assets 3 Identify entry points 4 Identify trust boundaries 5 Identify threats by category 6 Choose controls and note trade offs 7 Decide what you will monitor and what you will accept

vectors.title: Questions
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Questions
* What is the difference between an asset and a vulnerability * Why do trust boundaries matter more than components * Give one example of a threat that is not technical * If you had one day to improve security, how would threat modelling help you choose * Explain threat modelling to a colleague without using acronyms * Why is a threat model a living document

vectors.title: Attack paths how real breaches unfold
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Attack paths how real breaches unfold
Most breaches are not one clever trick. They are a chain of small wins. Attackers often start with access that looks harmless, then expand it.

vectors.title: Questions
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Questions
* Why is initial access often not the most damaging step * What is lateral movement in plain English * Why does privilege escalation change the whole incident * What does persistence mean and why is it dangerous * Where would you place detection if you could only place it in one stage

vectors.title: Defence in depth designing so one failure does not end you
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Defence in depth designing so one failure does not end you
Defence in depth is the idea that no single control is trusted to be perfect. The design goal is that one failure does not become total failure.

vectors.title: Control mapping as a discipline
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Control mapping as a discipline
A common failure in security programmes is controls without purpose. Each control should be traceable to a threat and a security property.

vectors.title: Questions
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Questions
* What does defence in depth mean in one sentence * Why is detection not a failure * Give an example of a control that reduces impact rather than likelihood * Why is recovery part of security * What is a single point of failure and how do you remove it

vectors.title: Identity and access management where most real security lives
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Identity and access management where most real security lives
In many organisations, security is identity. If you can control who can do what, you reduce the blast radius of almost everything.

vectors.title: Least privilege as a practical rule
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Least privilege as a practical rule
Least privilege is not a slogan. It is a design constraint: People should have only what they need, only when they need it, and only for as long as they need it.

vectors.title: Questions
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Questions
* What is the difference between authentication and authorisation * Why does admin access change the risk model * What is a session and why does session expiry matter * Why is least privilege hard in real organisations * Give an example where usability pushes against security and how you would handle it

vectors.title: Logs and telemetry evidence beats confidence
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Logs and telemetry evidence beats confidence
Many teams only realise they needed logs after a breach. Logs are not just for debugging. They are how you prove what happened.

vectors.title: What makes a log useful
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
What makes a log useful
A useful log is structured, time ordered, and correlated. It answers questions without guesswork.

vectors.title: Questions
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Questions
* Why does logging support non repudiation * What is the difference between logs and monitoring * Why do timestamps cause confusion * What is correlation and why is it powerful * What is a false positive and why does it matter for detection

vectors.title: Incident response staying calm when it is real
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Incident response staying calm when it is real
Security is partly design and partly behaviour under pressure. Incident response is the practice of doing the right things quickly when you do not know everything yet.

vectors.title: Triage as a decision problem
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Triage as a decision problem
Triage is not certainty. It is a decision under uncertainty. You often have partial signals.

vectors.title: Questions
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Questions
* Why is containment often the first priority * Why can deleting evidence make things worse * What is the difference between recovery and eradication * Why is communication part of incident response * What makes a good post incident review

vectors.title: Vulnerability management turning unknown risk into known work
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Vulnerability management turning unknown risk into known work
Most vulnerabilities are not cinematic. They are ordinary mistakes that remain unpatched.

vectors.title: Prioritisation that makes sense
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Prioritisation that makes sense
Prioritise by: Exploitability Exposure Business criticality Available mitigations Observed attacker behaviour

vectors.title: Questions
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Questions
* What is the difference between vulnerability, exploit, and incident * Why does exposure change risk * What is a compensating control * Why do patches sometimes increase risk temporarily * What is configuration drift

vectors.title: Ransomware and recovery the reality check
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Ransomware and recovery the reality check
Ransomware is not just encryption of files. Modern ransomware is a business model. It often includes data theft and extortion.

* Why do attackers target backups * What does restore testing prove * What is a dependency and why does it matter for recovery * What is double extortion * What is the business decision behind paying or not paying

This practice studio is designed to feel like real work, not a quiz.

Checkpoint
You understand this chapter if you can: Build a threat model for a feature and choose controls deliberately Explain a breach as an attack path and interrupt it Design defence in depth using prevent, detect, respond, recover Design least privilege roles and justify them Use logs to explain what happened Run a triage decision without panic Prioritise vulnerabi

vectors.title: Visual frameworks I lean on
vectors.text:
ch3.mdx
Visual frameworks I lean on
- Attack path grid: columns for access, execute, persist, escalate, move, impact. I place existing controls and see gaps. - Defence in depth rings: people, process, tech. I map each control to the ring and to CIA to spot single points of failure. - Identity flow: user -> IdP -> token -> app -> resource. I mark where logs must exist for authentication, author

vectors.title: Additional practice prompts
vectors.text:

Additional practice prompts
- Take one MITRE ATT&CK technique and map it to your own stack. Where would you detect it. - Redraw a recent breach story as an attack path and mark where one control would have stopped it. - Create a tiny runbook for MFA fatigue: signals, thresholds, actions, evidence to keep.

vectors.title: Threat modelling and attacker thinking
vectors.text:
Applied Cybersecurity
Threat modelling and attacker thinking
Security improves fastest when I can answer one question clearly: what matters, who might attack it, and how it could fail.

vectors.title: Attack surfaces and common failure classes
vectors.text:
Applied Cybersecurity
Attack surfaces and common failure classes
Most breaches start with what is exposed, not with exotic zero days.

vectors.title: Authentication, sessions and access control
vectors.text:
Applied Cybersecurity
Authentication, sessions and access control
Authentication answers who you are. Authorisation answers what you may do. Sessions remember you between requests. Mixing them up is why many breaches feel trivial.

vectors.title: Logging, monitoring and risk thinking
vectors.text:
Applied Cybersecurity
Logging, monitoring and risk thinking
Prevention is never perfect. Good detection shortens the time between a bad action and your response.

This level is for people who want to understand how systems fail and how we defend them. We build on the Foundations and start to think like attackers and defenders.

vectors.title: Identity centric defence and resilient platforms
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Cloud and Platform Security
Identity centric defence and resilient platforms
Cloud makes identity the control plane. My job is to design guardrails, verify shared responsibility, and keep recovery paths ready.

vectors.title: 1. Decision How to enforce least privilege in cloud
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Cloud and Platform Security
1. Decision How to enforce least privilege in cloud
Permissions sprawl quickly. I design landing zones, baseline policies, and automated checks.

vectors.title: 2. Decision Which dependencies are safe enough
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Cloud and Platform Security
2. Decision Which dependencies are safe enough
Cloud stacks rely on many managed services and images. I identify critical dependencies and plan verification.

vectors.title: 3. Evidence and readiness
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Cloud and Platform Security
3. Evidence and readiness
I need proof that controls work: guardrail tests, break-glass drills, backup restores, and audit trails.

vectors.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Cloud and Platform Security
4. Ethics and accountability
Cloud decisions affect cost, performance, and user trust. I document trade offs and ensure privacy and accessibility are respected.

vectors.title: Signals, certainty, and containment
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Detection and Response Analyst
Signals, certainty, and containment
I live in ambiguity. My decisions must balance false positives, false negatives, and business impact. Ethics matters when action affects users.

vectors.title: 1. Decision Which signals matter most
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Detection and Response Analyst
1. Decision Which signals matter most
Signal quality beats signal quantity. I prioritise signals that give high certainty with low noise.

vectors.title: 2. Decision When to act
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Detection and Response Analyst
2. Decision When to act
Acting too early can disrupt business; acting too late increases impact. I document thresholds.

vectors.title: 3. Incident realism Build the timeline
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Detection and Response Analyst
3. Incident realism Build the timeline
title="Walk an incident timeline" description="Practise choosing containment, communication, and recovery steps under time pressure." >

vectors.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Detection and Response Analyst
4. Ethics and accountability
Containment can affect users. I apply least harm: preserve safety, respect privacy, and justify disruption.

vectors.title: Practitioner track
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Notes: Practitioner track
Practitioner track

vectors.title: Role based decision making
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity Notes: Practitioner track
Role based decision making
This track is not about knowing terms. It is about making decisions that affect real people. Each page is a role. Each section is a decision. Each decision is tied to evidence and consequences.

vectors.title: Roles
vectors.text:

Roles

vectors.title: Designing for defensible systems
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Architect
Designing for defensible systems
My job is to design systems that fail safely. I make assumptions explicit, reduce blast radius, and ensure the system is observable.

vectors.title: 1. Decision Which assumptions are allowed
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Architect
1. Decision Which assumptions are allowed
Architecture is mostly assumptions. I catalogue them, challenge them, and design controls to catch when they fail.

vectors.title: 2. Decision How to prove the design is secure
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Architect
2. Decision How to prove the design is secure
Designs without evidence are optimistic. I need artefacts that show the design resists expected attacks.

vectors.title: 3. Incident realism When architecture fails
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Architect
3. Incident realism When architecture fails
title="Architecture failure rehearsal" description="Walk through an incident where a boundary fails. Decide what isolates, what alerts, and what recovers first." >

vectors.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Architect
4. Ethics and accountability
Design choices affect safety, privacy, and inclusivity. I document impacts and seek consent when risk shifts to users.

vectors.title: Decisions, evidence, and safe delivery
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Engineer
Decisions, evidence, and safe delivery
This role lives close to systems. The work is not to add controls randomly. The work is to choose controls that reduce risk measurably without breaking the product.

vectors.title: 1. Decision What is the threat model for this change
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Engineer
1. Decision What is the threat model for this change
I must define what I am defending and against whom. Without this, controls become theatre.

vectors.title: 2. Decision What evidence proves the control works
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Engineer
2. Decision What evidence proves the control works
Controls that cannot be tested are beliefs, not security.

vectors.title: 3. Incident realism A timeline I must be ready for
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Engineer
3. Incident realism A timeline I must be ready for
title="Walk through an incident timeline" description="Practise containment, evidence preservation, and recovery decisions." >

vectors.title: 4. Ethics and accountability
vectors.text:
Practitioner: Security Engineer
4. Ethics and accountability
Security changes affect users. I keep friction proportional to risk. I avoid collecting unnecessary data. I am honest about uncertainty.

vectors.title: From organisation to ecosystem
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Advanced
From organisation to ecosystem
At earlier levels, digitalisation work was mostly inside one organisation. At this level it sits in ecosystems: supply chains, regulators, partners, platforms, and competitors share the same data flows and standards. A weak link in one place can hurt many others.

vectors.title: Regulation, policy, and trust
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Advanced
Regulation, policy, and trust
Digitalisation at scale is shaped by regulation and policy. Regulation can enable change when guardrails are clear, or block it when rules are rigid or fragmented. Incentives can also push risk into the wrong places.

vectors.title: Interoperability and cross-border thinking
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Advanced
Interoperability and cross-border thinking
As data, services, or platforms cross organisational or national boundaries, interoperability becomes central. It is not only technical; it involves shared meaning, process alignment, legal agreements, and operational coordination.

vectors.title: Funding models and economic reality
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Advanced
Funding models and economic reality
Ambitious digitalisation needs realistic funding. The funding model is an architectural choice: project funding versus product and platform funding, central versus distributed investment, and charging models for platforms and data.

vectors.title: Risk, resilience, and learning from failure
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Advanced
Risk, resilience, and learning from failure
At this level we assume things will go wrong: systems fail, partners are compromised, regulations change, and some projects miss targets. The question is how we design for resilience and how we learn.

vectors.title: Stewardship and long-term digital health
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Advanced
Stewardship and long-term digital health
Stewardship recognises that digital choices today shape options for years. Data, platforms, and standards can become de facto public infrastructure. Skills, culture, and trust take time to build and can be lost quickly.

vectors.title: What digitalisation really is
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
What digitalisation really is
Digitalisation is the deliberate redesign of how an organisation creates value using digital technology, data, and new ways of working.

vectors.title: Why digitalisation matters
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
Why digitalisation matters
Digitalisation matters because expectations are higher, complexity is greater, and competition and scrutiny are sharper. People compare every service to the best digital products they use daily. Manual processes cannot keep up with data, regulation, and risk.

vectors.title: Digitisation vs digitalisation vs digital transformation
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
Digitisation vs digitalisation vs digital transformation
Plain: Converting analogue information into digital form, such as scanning paper into PDF. Formal: Transforming analogue artefacts into digital representations without altering the underlying process.

vectors.title: Data as a strategic asset
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
Data as a strategic asset
Data becomes an asset when it is correct enough to trust, accessible enough to use, governed enough to protect, and connected enough to create insight. Treating data strategically means deciding who is responsible, how it is collected, stored, shared, measured, and used safely.

vectors.title: People and culture
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
People and culture
Culture is the hard part. Systems succeed only when people trust them, know how to use them, and are supported to change habits. A digital culture shows up in the questions people ask: do we use data to decide, do we share information, do we test ideas, do we treat security and privacy as design constraints.

vectors.title: Processes and technology foundations
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
Processes and technology foundations
If you automate a broken process, you get a faster broken process.

vectors.title: Planning and maturity
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
Planning and maturity
Digitalisation is a journey in three horizons: short term visible wins, medium term shared platforms and data foundations, long term operating model change. Maturity models help if used to decide realistic next steps, not to chase a score.

vectors.title: Observing digitalisation in practice
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Beginner
Observing digitalisation in practice
Digitalisation must be observable. It should show up in usage of digital channels, time saved, platform adoption, and indicators of data quality. Measuring change is part of doing digitalisation well.

vectors.title: From foundations to design
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Intermediate
From foundations to design
The beginner page established that digitalisation is about value, people, process, data, and technology working together. At this level the questions change from “what is digitalisation” to:

vectors.title: Vision, outcomes, and value
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Intermediate
Vision, outcomes, and value
A lot of strategies fail because they start with technology. I start with a small set of clear outcomes that matter to real people.

vectors.title: Operating model and capabilities
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Intermediate
Operating model and capabilities
Digitalisation changes how the organisation runs. An operating model describes how people, process, technology, and governance work together to deliver value.

vectors.title: Platforms, data, and architecture for digitalisation
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Intermediate
Platforms, data, and architecture for digitalisation
Technology now becomes more concrete but remains strategy led. The question is which shared platforms support the capabilities and outcomes we need, how data moves safely, and what architectural approach keeps change easier rather than harder.

vectors.title: Governance, funding, and risk
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Intermediate
Governance, funding, and risk
Digitalisation touches risk, money, and responsibility, so governance becomes central. Governance here is not long policy documents; it is clear answers to who owns the roadmap, who can approve platforms or major changes, how data and privacy decisions are made, and how security standards are enforced.

vectors.title: Roadmapping and prioritisation
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Intermediate
Roadmapping and prioritisation
Even with a clear vision, operating model, and platform view, we cannot do everything at once. Roadmapping is the sequence of what changes when and why. Dependencies matter: analytics needs data quality first; identity should stabilise before modernising every small application.

vectors.title: Practice and reflection
vectors.text:
Digitalisation Strategy Notes - Intermediate
Practice and reflection
This dashboard gives a feel for the signals a digital leader might track: adoption of digital channels, use of core platforms, progress against roadmap milestones, and basic quality indicators. Strategy and measurement belong together.

Decomposition is the process of breaking a system into parts. Good decomposition is the difference between a system that scales and one that collapses under its own weight.

vectors.title: Introduction
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity notes
Introduction
Security protects confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Ask three quick questions: what must stay secret, what must stay accurate, and what must stay online? Those answers guide every control.

vectors.title: Symmetric encryption
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity notes
Symmetric encryption
One shared key locks and unlocks data. It is fast and proven (AES), but the shared key must be exchanged safely. Think of a locker code: if it leaks, privacy is gone.

vectors.title: Asymmetric encryption
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity notes
Asymmetric encryption
Two keys: a public key to lock, a private key to unlock. Share the public key openly; never share the private key. This removes the need for a pre-shared secret.

vectors.title: Hashing in practice
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity notes
Hashing in practice
A hash turns any input into a fixed-length fingerprint. Small input changes produce large output changes. Hashes support integrity checks and password storage (with salts and slow functions).

vectors.title: Quick check
vectors.text:
Cybersecurity notes
Quick check
- Which part stays secret in asymmetric encryption? - Why does symmetric encryption not solve key exchange on its own? - When would you choose hashing instead of encryption?

vectors.text:
Generate draft architecture diagrams from structured inputs.
Inputs: systemName (string) max 80 chars; systemDescription (string) max 600 chars; audience (enum) students|professionals; goal (enum) explain|design-review|security-review|data-review; actors/blocks/flows/security (arrays) capped by ARCH_DIAGRAM_LIMITS
Limits: Field length caps; diagram counts constrained by ARCH_DIAGRAM_LIMITS
Outputs: Mermaid diagrams, SVG/PNG downloads, Architecture brief, ADR stubs
RunPath: local
Errors: validation_error, generation_error, user_error

vectors.title: game-canvas
vectors.text:
Interactive games with keyboard and touch; offline after first load.
Inputs: 
Limits: Offline caching after first load; device input required.
Outputs: Run metrics, Skill review
RunPath: local
Errors: not_found, locked_route, offline_not_ready

vectors.title: vision-quick-check
vectors.text:
Validate and preview images; guide on size/format.
Inputs: image (file) png/jpg/webp within lab size limit
Limits: File size cap; supported formats png/jpg/webp.
Outputs: Validation result, Preview, Size/format guidance
RunPath: compute-runner
Errors: file_too_large, unsupported_format, processing_error

vectors.title: speech-sound-analysis
vectors.text:
Analyze uploaded/recorded audio; transcript and basic metrics.
Inputs: audio (file|recording) wav/mp3 within duration+size caps
Limits: Duration cap; filesize cap; recording requires browser support.
Outputs: Transcript, Duration, Loudness/peaks summary
RunPath: compute-runner
Errors: recording_unsupported, file_too_large, unsupported_format, processing_error

vectors.title: code-lab
vectors.text:
Run code safely in a sandbox with allowlisted languages.
Inputs: code (string) per-language size limit; language (enum) allowlist only
Limits: CPU/memory/time quotas; no outbound network; package policy enforced.
Outputs: stdout, stderr, exit status, resource usage summary
RunPath: compute-runner
Errors: validation_error, timeout, resource_limit, runtime_error, policy_denied
